Use Case 01

Paolo Sonego

Source: vignettes/usecase01.Rmd
usecase01.Rmd

Abstract

How to query COMPASS from R

VESPUCCI is the gene expression database for grapevine and we can access it via its GraphQL interface, called COMPASS. The rCOMPASS package is a R package that wraps some functionalities to simplify communication with the COMPASS interface.

In this first exercise we will perform few basic operations with VESPUCCI. We will create a Module starting from few genes and then automatically extend it by adding more genes. We will also have a look at gene and samples annotations.:

# devtools::install_github("onertipaday/rcompass")
library(rcompass)
#> 
#> This is 'rCOMPASS' version 0.0.3 based on COMPASS version 0.8.0.

The COMPASS GraphQL endpoint might hosts different compendia. At the moment there is only the VESPUCCI compendium, but there are different version of VESPUCCI, and each version might have data normalized in different ways. In this case there are 2 versions of VESPUCCI, version 1.0 (legacy) and version 2.0 (latest). The latter has data normalized in 2 different ways, TPM normalization and LIMMA (the default one) while the legacy version has the legacy normalization only (i.e. per-sample logratios). For every query we will need to indicate the compendium we want to use, if no version, no normalization and no database is specified the default values will be used.

get_available_compendia()
#> $info
#>                                   name                               fullName 
#>                             "vespucci"                             "VESPUCCI" 
#>                            description 
#> "The Vitis gene expression compendium" 
#> 
#> $versions
#> $versions[[1]]
#>            versionNumber           databases.name databases.normalizations 
#>                    "1.0"         "vitis_vinifera"       "legacy (default)" 
#> 
#> $versions[[2]]
#>             versionNumber            databases.name databases.normalizations1 
#>                     "2.0"          "vitis_vinifera"              "tpm_sample" 
#> databases.normalizations2 
#>         "limma (default)"

Genes

Let’s build our module starting from a bunch of genes that might come from a previous analysis. Gene name used are the VIT_ ids

gene_names <- c('VIT_00s0246g00220','VIT_00s0332g00060','VIT_00s0332g00110','VIT_00s0332g00160','VIT_00s0396g00010','VIT_00s0505g00030','VIT_00s0505g00060','VIT_00s0873g00020','VIT_00s0904g00010')

We can query the compendium with the list of gene names and get a list of BiologicalFeature objects that represents our genes of interest. The easiest way to know which are the valid filter values to be used is to use the autocompletion (ALT + SPACEBAR) in the COMPASS GraphQL interface at http://compass.fmach.it/graphql.

bf_ids <- get_biofeature_id(compendium = "vespucci", name_In = gene_names)
DT::datatable(bf_ids)

Genes might have different aliases, all of which are defined in VESPUCCI as annotations. Since annotations (for both genes and samples) are represented as RDF triples using different ontologies, we can perform a SPARQL query to retrieve all the biological features (genes here) that has an alias (NCIT_C41095 term on the NCIT Ontology, http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/) equal to the ones specified in the list. 
my_query <- "SELECT ?s ?p ?o WHERE { {?s <http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/NCIT_C41095> 'B9S8R7'} UNION {?s <http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/NCIT_C41095> 'Q7M2G6'} UNION {?s <http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/NCIT_C41095> 'D7SZ93'} UNION {?s <http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/NCIT_C41095> 'B8XIJ8'} UNION {?s <http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/NCIT_C41095> 'Vv00s0125g00280'} UNION {?s <http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/NCIT_C41095> 'Vv00s0187g00140'} UNION {?s <http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/NCIT_C41095> 'Vv00s0246g00010'} UNION {?s <http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/NCIT_C41095> 'Vv00s0246g00080'} UNION {?s <http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/NCIT_C41095> 'Vv00s0438g00020'} UNION {?s <http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/NCIT_C41095> 'Vv00s0246g00200'} }"
sparql_results <- get_sparql_annotation_triples(target = "biofeature", query = my_query)
sparql_results[,1]
#>  [1] QmlvRmVhdHVyZVR5cGU6MjcwOTc= QmlvRmVhdHVyZVR5cGU6Mjg1MDQ=
#>  [3] QmlvRmVhdHVyZVR5cGU6Mjc1NTU= QmlvRmVhdHVyZVR5cGU6Mjg2MzA=
#>  [5] QmlvRmVhdHVyZVR5cGU6MjY0MzM= QmlvRmVhdHVyZVR5cGU6MjY4ODM=
#>  [7] QmlvRmVhdHVyZVR5cGU6Mjc0MjM= QmlvRmVhdHVyZVR5cGU6Mjc0MjY=
#>  [9] QmlvRmVhdHVyZVR5cGU6MjgxODM= QmlvRmVhdHVyZVR5cGU6Mjc0Mzc=
#> 10 Levels: QmlvRmVhdHVyZVR5cGU6Mjc0MjM= ... QmlvRmVhdHVyZVR5cGU6MjY4ODM=

or we can use the wrapper function get_ids_from_alias():

aliases <- c('B9S8R7','Q7M2G6','D7SZ93','B8XIJ8','Vv00s0125g00280','Vv00s0187g00140','Vv00s0246g00010','Vv00s0246g00080','Vv00s0438g00020','Vv00s0246g00200')
get_ids_from_alias(target = "biofeature", alias_names = aliases)
#>  [1] QmlvRmVhdHVyZVR5cGU6MjcwOTc= QmlvRmVhdHVyZVR5cGU6Mjg1MDQ=
#>  [3] QmlvRmVhdHVyZVR5cGU6Mjc1NTU= QmlvRmVhdHVyZVR5cGU6Mjg2MzA=
#>  [5] QmlvRmVhdHVyZVR5cGU6MjY0MzM= QmlvRmVhdHVyZVR5cGU6MjY4ODM=
#>  [7] QmlvRmVhdHVyZVR5cGU6Mjc0MjM= QmlvRmVhdHVyZVR5cGU6Mjc0MjY=
#>  [9] QmlvRmVhdHVyZVR5cGU6MjgxODM= QmlvRmVhdHVyZVR5cGU6Mjc0Mzc=
#> 10 Levels: QmlvRmVhdHVyZVR5cGU6Mjc0MjM= ... QmlvRmVhdHVyZVR5cGU6MjY4ODM=

Another examples returning samples ids selected by PO ontology term seed:

my_query <- paste0('SELECT ?s ?p ?o WHERE { ?s <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#type>',
'<http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/NCIT_C19157>',
'. ?s <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#type>',
'<http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/PO_0009010>}')
get_sparql_annotation_triples(target = "sample", query = my_query)[,1]
#>  [1] U2FtcGxlVHlwZToxMDI4 U2FtcGxlVHlwZTozMDQ5 U2FtcGxlVHlwZTo3MTY=
#>  [4] U2FtcGxlVHlwZTo3MTA= U2FtcGxlVHlwZTo3MTQ= U2FtcGxlVHlwZTo3MTM=
#>  [7] U2FtcGxlVHlwZTo3MTE= U2FtcGxlVHlwZTo3MjE= U2FtcGxlVHlwZTo3MTk=
#> [10] U2FtcGxlVHlwZTo3MTc= U2FtcGxlVHlwZTo3MjA= U2FtcGxlVHlwZTo3MTU=
#> [13] U2FtcGxlVHlwZTo3MTI= U2FtcGxlVHlwZTo3MTg= U2FtcGxlVHlwZToxMDMx
#> [16] U2FtcGxlVHlwZToxMDMy U2FtcGxlVHlwZToxMDMz U2FtcGxlVHlwZToxMDM0
#> [19] U2FtcGxlVHlwZToxMDM1 U2FtcGxlVHlwZToxMDM2 U2FtcGxlVHlwZToxMDM3
#> [22] U2FtcGxlVHlwZToxMDM4 U2FtcGxlVHlwZToxMDM5 U2FtcGxlVHlwZToxMDQw
#> [25] U2FtcGxlVHlwZToxMDQx U2FtcGxlVHlwZToxMDQy U2FtcGxlVHlwZToxMDQz
#> [28] U2FtcGxlVHlwZToxMDQ0 U2FtcGxlVHlwZToxMDQ1 U2FtcGxlVHlwZToxMDQ2
#> [31] U2FtcGxlVHlwZToxMDQ3 U2FtcGxlVHlwZToxMDQ4 U2FtcGxlVHlwZToxMDI5
#> [34] U2FtcGxlVHlwZToxMDMw U2FtcGxlVHlwZTozMDQ0 U2FtcGxlVHlwZTozMDQ1
#> [37] U2FtcGxlVHlwZTozMDQ2 U2FtcGxlVHlwZTozMDQ3 U2FtcGxlVHlwZTozMDQ4
#> 39 Levels: U2FtcGxlVHlwZTo3MjA= U2FtcGxlVHlwZTo3MjE= ... U2FtcGxlVHlwZTozMDQ5

Each BiologicalFeature object has several fields. In our case, since the BiologicalFeature represent a gene, we have sequence. The id is the identifier used internally in the database.

DT::datatable(get_biofeature_by_name(name_In = gene_names))

# Create a Module We are now ready to create our first module. If we pass a list of genes (BiologicalFeature objects) it will automatically retrieve the “best” conditions (SampleSet objects). 
module_1 <- create_module(biofeaturesNames=gene_names, version = "legacy")

A module can be thought as a matrix composed by BiologicalFeature objects (genes in our case) as rows and SampleSet objects (conditions contrasts in our case) as columns. Each SampleSet, as the name suggests, is composed by 1 or more Sample objects. Since we are using the legacy normalization each SampleSet is composed by 2 samples, one Test sample and one Reference sample and the value associated is the logratio between the Test and Reference for a specific gene (BiologicalFeature).

DT::datatable(module_1, class = 'cell-border stripe')
# get_sample_by_gsm(sampleName_Icontains="GSM1313535")
# get_sampleset_id(name_In = "GSM605594.ch1-vs-GSM605578.ch1")
get_sampleset_id(name_In = colnames(module_1)[1:10])
#>                          id                             name
#> 1  U2FtcGxlU2V0VHlwZTo5OTg= GSM1020449.ch1-vs-GSM1020442.ch1
#> 2  U2FtcGxlU2V0VHlwZTo5OTk= GSM1020450.ch1-vs-GSM1020442.ch1
#> 3  U2FtcGxlU2V0VHlwZToxMDE1 GSM1020468.ch1-vs-GSM1020460.ch1
#> 4  U2FtcGxlU2V0VHlwZTo3Njc=   GSM881525.ch1-vs-GSM881520.ch1
#> 5  U2FtcGxlU2V0VHlwZTo4MDM=   GSM881559.ch1-vs-GSM881550.ch1
#> 6  U2FtcGxlU2V0VHlwZTo4MDU=   GSM881561.ch1-vs-GSM881550.ch1
#> 7  U2FtcGxlU2V0VHlwZTo4NzQ=   GSM881592.ch1-vs-GSM881586.ch1
#> 8  U2FtcGxlU2V0VHlwZTo4NzU=   GSM881593.ch1-vs-GSM881586.ch1
#> 9  U2FtcGxlU2V0VHlwZTo4NzY=   GSM881594.ch1-vs-GSM881586.ch1
#> 10 U2FtcGxlU2V0VHlwZTo5MjM=   GSM881677.ch1-vs-GSM881670.ch1

Plot a module

The easiest way to visualize a module is using a heatmap. The Plot object wraps a module and can return different plot type with different format (the Plotly JSON format or HTML). To see an heatmap embedded in a Jupyter Notebook we can retrieve the HTML code of the Plot (that uses Plotly) and display it directly into the notebook.

#' my_plot_html <- plot_heatmap(plot_type = "heatmap",
#' biofeaturesNames = gene_names, normalization = "legacy")

Alternatively you can use directly any R function to cluster data and produce an heatmap, e.g.:

# library(heatmaply)
# my_h <- heatmaply(module_1,
#           showticklabels = c(TRUE, TRUE),
#           fontsize_col = 7.5,
#           col = gplots::greenred(50),
#           plot_method = 'plotly')
# my_h
library(pheatmap)
pheat_cl <- pheatmap::pheatmap(mat =  as.matrix(module_1))
pheat_cl

Biological Features (genes) and Sample Sets (contrasts) have no particular order in a module. But since the heatmap is clustered we can retrieve the sorted list of Biological Features and Sample Sets respectively. An easy way is to use a the variable containing the order for both rows and columns produced by the pheatmap function.

DT::datatable(module_1[pheat_cl$tree_row$order,pheat_cl$tree_col$order])

# Plot correlation network Given a module we can plot the correlation network between Biological Features (genes) by looking at the Pearson correlation coefficient of the module’s Sample Sets (contrast). The default threshold is 0.7, but it can be changed. Edges in orange represent anti-correlation.

Automatically expand a module

One of the classic way to use VESPUCCI is to start with a set of genes selected from previous analysis, have a look at the top conditions in which they show a consistent (and strong) behavior and then look for other genes that behave the same across those same conditions. The way to do it is to plot the distribution of genes that show a similar behavior of the module’s genes across the same condition in order pick up a suitable threshold.

For example, if we pick a threshold around 0.65 (looking at the top plot) we might expect to have around 30 Biological Features (genes) with a score equal or greater than that, to be added in our module. In this case let’s just pick the top 30 genes and create e new module.

The new module is created by adding Biological Feature objects to the old module. This operation will modify the module object in-place, so we might want to clone the module_1 object first, if we don’t want to lose it, or we might want to save it in a local file and then create e new module by simply loading it.

We can have a look at the heatmap of the new module

Annotations

In VESPUCCI, both Biological Feature (gene) and Sample annotations are represented using RDF. We can visualize annotation as a set of RDF triples.

Another way is to visualize the annotation is with RDF graph.

Annotations can also be used to retrieve Sample or Biological Features (gene) starting from a SPARQL query. For example we might want to select all seed Sample.

sparql = "SELECT ?s ?p ?o WHERE { ?s <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#type> <http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/NCIT_C19157> . ?s <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#type> <http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/PO_0009010>}"

The term NCIT_C19157 indicates specimen while PO_0009010 is the Plant Ontology term for seed. To indicate a gene, instead the term NCIT_C16612 is used.

seed_samples <- get_sparql_annotation_triples(target = "sample", query = sparql)[,1]

Now we can collect all the Sample Sets in which these samples are used and then create a new module based on Sample Sets only leaving VESPUCCI to figure out which are the genes (Biological Feature objects) that show a consistent up or down-regulated profile.

# module_3 <- create_module(samplesetNames = seed_samples, useIds = TRUE)

And now we can plot the heatmap

# pheatmap::pheatmap(mat = as.matrix(module_3))
